OVERVIEW: The Gany series consists of very deep, well drained, moderately permeable soils on mountains. They formed in slope alluvium or colluvium from limestone. Slopes are 30 to 70 percent. Average annual precipitation is about 24 inches and the average annual temperature is about 36 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Typic Calcicryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Gany gravelly loam, on a 55 percent north-facing slope at 6,600 feet elevation in forestland. (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated. When described on September 18, 1984, the soil was dry to 21 inches and moist below this depth.)
Oi--0.5 to 0 inches; slightly decomposed needles, twigs, leaves, and grass. (0.5 to 3 inches thick)
A--0 to 6 inches; brown (10YR 4/3) gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and fine and few medium roots; common very fine and fine interstitial and few very fine and fine tubular pores; 30 percent pebbles; 2 percent cobbles; slightly alkaline (pH 7.6); clear smooth boundary. (6 to 15 inches thick)
Bk1--6 to 13 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and fine and few medium and coarse roots; common very fine and fine interstitial and few very fine and fine tubular pores; 35 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles; lime coatings 1/16 inch thick on the undersides of coarse fragments; strongly effervescent; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); gradual wavy boundary. (4 to 16 inches thick)
Bk2--13 to 21 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) very gravelly loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine, fine and medium roots; common very fine tubular pores; 35 percent pebbles; lime coatings 1/16 inch thick on the undersides and sides of coarse fragments; violently effervescent (25 percent calcium carbonate equivalent); moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); clear wavy boundary. (6 to 20 inches thick)
Bk3--21 to 32 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely gravelly sandy loam, light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; common very fine and fine and few medium roots; common very fine and few fine tubular pores; 35 percent pebbles, 25 percent cobbles, 2 percent stones; lime coatings 1/16 inch thick on all sides of rock fragments; violently effervescent (35 percent calcium carbonate equivalent); moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); gradual wavy boundary. (0 to 15 inches thick).
Bkq1--32 to 46 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely gravelly sandy loam, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) moist; single grain; loose; common very fine and fine and few medium roots; few very fine tubular and interstitial pores; 60 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles; lime and silica coatings 1/16 to 1/8 inch thick on all sides of coarse fragments; violently effervescent (30 percent calcium carbonate equivalent); moderately alkaline (pH 8.3); gradual wavy boundary. (0 to 16 inches thick).
Bkq2--46 to 60 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely gravelly sandy loam, light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) moist; single grain; loose; common very fine and fine and few medium and coarse roots; few very fine tubular and interstitial pores; 45 percent pebbles, 30 percent cobbles; lime and silica coatings 1/16 to 1/8 inch thick on all sides of coarse fragments; strongly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Custer County, Idaho; approximately 1 mile southeast of Bayhorse, Idaho; about 1,750 feet west and 700 feet south of the northeast corner of section 11, T. 12 N., R. 18 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Average annual soil temperature - 35 to 39 degrees F.
Average summer soil temperature - 44 to 47 degress F.
Moisture control section - between 8 and 24 inches; dry throughout the moisture control section for 30 to 45 consecutive days during the four months following the summer solstice
Mollic epipedon thickness - 7 to 15 inches
Control section percent clay - 10 to 22
Rock fragments - 40 to 90 percent
Calcium carbonate equivalent, weighted average - 25 to 40 percent
Depth to carbonates - 0 to 7 inches
Depth to calcic horizon - 0 to 15 inches
Calcareous to the surface after mixing the upper 7 inches
A horizon - Hue: 7.5YR, 10YR or 2.5Y
Value: 4 or 5 dry, 2, 3, or 4 moist
Chroma: 2 or 3 dry or moist
Rock fragments: 15 to 80 percent
Reaction: slightly alkaline or moderately alkaline
Bk horizons - Hue: 7.5YR, 10YR, or 2.5Y
Value: 4 through 7 dry, 4 through 6 moist
Chroma: 2, 3 or 4 dry or moist
Texture: GRV-L, GRX-L, GRX-SL, GRX-SIL
Rock fragments: 35 to 90 percent
Reaction: slightly alkaline or moderately alkaline
Bkq horizons - Hue: 7.5YR, 10YR, or 2.5Y
Value: 5, 6 or 7 dry, 4, 5 or 6 moist
Chroma: 2 through 6 dry or moist
Texture: GRX-SL, GRX-L
Rock fragments - 60 to 90 percent
Reaction: slightly alkaline or moderately alkaline

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: This is Eagar series. Eagar soils do not have Bkq horizons and have a lithologic discontinuity.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Gany soils are on mountains. These soils formed in slope alluvium or colluvium from limestone. Slopes are 30 to 70 percent. Elevations are 5,200 to 9,800 feet. The climate is cold and moist in winter and spring, and cool and dry in the summer. The average annual precipitation is 18 to 28 inches, average annual temperature is 34 to 39 degrees F., and the frost-free period is 10 to 40 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Adek(T), Meegernot(T), Nitchly(T), and Zeelnot(T) soils. Adek soils are on windswept ridges and have ochric epipedons. Meegernot soils are on mountains and have pachic epipedons. Nitchly and Zeelnot soils are on mountains and have ochric epipedons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Well drained; medium runoff; moderate premeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: Forestland. Vegetation is mainly Douglas-fir, common juniper, subalpine fir, mountain snowberry and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: East-central Idaho. These soils are of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Mollic epipedon - The zone from the soil surface to a depth of 7 inches must be mixed to meet mollic requirements (A horizon, upper 1 inch of Bk1 horizon).
Calcic horizon - The zone from 6 to 46 inches (Bk, Bkq horizons)
Particle-size control section - The zone from 10 to 40 inches (part of Bk1, the Bk2 and Bk3, part of Bkq1).
Moisture regime - udic
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
